title.narrative: Renforcement des capacités entrepreneuriales des femmes et jeunes dans le secteur agroalimentaire informel dans le Nord- Bénin à travers la formation-coaching et l’incubation des entreprises

description.narrative: Chaîne des résultats : Impact à long term : Contribuer à la fin de la faim et l’amélioration la sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle à travers le renforcement des capacités, des connaissances et qualité aussi bien des individus que des organisations dans le domaine de la Formation Technique et Professionnelle et de l’Enseignement Supérieure au Bénin. Impacts à moyen terme : (i) Les partenariats entre individus et organisations sont inclusifs et durables et (collaboration UP-KIT et UP-monde professionnel local) (ii) Les organisations clés pour le développement sectoriel inclusif des pays partenaires sont renforcées par l’influx des travailleurs qualifiés (diplômés qui appliquent connaissances acquises, emploi des diplômés). Outcome : Les connaissances et compétences des individus et organisations sont améliorées selon les exigences spécifiques du marché de travail national/régional et visent l’inclusion (dans les pays partenaires et aux Pays Bas) (. Outputs : (i) Besoins en formation identifiés/précisés, (ii) Formations organisées et données, (iii) Matériel pédagogique disponible et (iv) Résultats des évaluations de la formation TMT disponibles.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Dépt Communication Unuiversité de Parakou
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
**Extent to which capacity building needs have been addressed**. Although teachers of the relevant UP departments (agronomy, economics and rural sociology) master basic concepts for business development and entrepreneurship, they did not all have the required knowledge and skills that are needed to accompany small and medium enterprises. This situation slows down the ardor and dedication of teachers to educate and train students as future entrepreneurs and coach local entrepreneurs who want expand their business. This joint UP-KIT TMT project provided 22 university teachers of the most relevant departments with the required concepts, approaches and practical methods and tools. According to the results of the participants’ evaluations of the two training-workshops, the TMT project succeeded in achieving this aim as initially defined by the university.
In addition, the curricula of relevant UP departments include modules on business development and entrepreneurship in general, but not specifically for the agrifood sector. Various teachers asked to be trained in concepts and methods that are linked to socio-economic realities of the largely informal agri-food sector and its potential to contribute to food and nutritional security. The training-workshops therefore focused on the local agrifood sector (e.g. quick scan study prior to the trainings) and included exchanges between teachers and local entrepreneurs (field visits, interviews, and joint practical exercises during trainings). Although the trained teachers indicated that they will ‘quite/highly likely’ apply the required knowledge and skills, it also depends on UP senior management whether this will be materialized. This aim of the TMT project was thus partially achieved.
**Lessons learnt**. The results from the participants’ evaluations of the trainings revealed that they very much appreciated the exchanges with local agrifood entrepreneurs, which allowed them to be acquainted with the daily reality of women or young entrepreneurs. Consequently, the programme of the second training was built upon exercises around real-life business cases.
Lessons learnt from this experience: (i) extensive participatory evaluations are key and instrumental in adapting training trajectories that focus on practical tools and skills; and (ii) capacity strengthening goes beyond ‘training’ (the basic activity of this TMT project) and should include facilitation of stakeholder interaction with a clearly defined training objective.
The changes made to the TMT project, which already started (Oct 2019) before the COVID-19 pandemic, forced KIT as the training service supplier to work from a distance; i.e. relying on local consultants and trainers and using digital communication tools.
Lessons learnt from these adaptations: (iii) the training service supplier (KIT) needs to have an extensive in-country network of experienced trainers, on whom it can rely (commitment, availability and quality); and (iv) both the requesting organization (UP) and service supplier (KIT) need to strengthen staff’s capacity in using digital platforms and tools for training purposes.
**Recommendations for the University of Parakou**. Based on the above-mentioned lessons learnt, (i) the relevant UP departments could strengthen linkages with local networks and associations of (female and young) entrepreneurs in order to institutionalize exchanges between teachers and entrepreneurs ; and (ii) UP should invest in collective equipment for facilitating the use of digital platforms and tools for education and training purposes (NB: during the TMT trajectory, the UP TMT coordinator and trainees relied upon their personal equipment for KIT back-stopping).

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
Prior to the 1st training-workshop, a small team of UP researchers conducted a quick scan of the local agri-food sector by assessing the demand for capacity strengthening (interviews of 60 entrepreneurs; 59% women and 58% youth) and the supply of courses and training by UP (15 teachers interviewed). The results of these interviews allowed for asserting the training topics that were identified in the project proposal, and prioritizing topics. Target value = 1 field study report; actual value = 1 field study report (100%).
The UP and KIT jointly organized two training-workshop: the first one focused on basic concepts and approaches for agri-food enterprise development and the second one on practical methods and tools for proving business advice to entrepreneurs. The programme of the 2nd training mainly consisted of practical exercises for which four business owners were participated in the training. Target value = 2 trainings; actual value = 2 trainings (100%).
Strictly speaking, no training guidelines were produced. It was agreed upon with the UP TMT coordinator to produce instead technical sheets (9 sheets) that briefly explain the methods and tools. This allows teachers to adapt the material and integrate it into courses for which already pedagogical guidelines exist. Furthermore, all participating teachers received the material (background literature, practical exercises) that was used for the training-workshops. Target value = 3 training guidelines; actual value = 0 guidelines (0%).
During the training-workshops, especially during the second one, exercises were organized around the use of business development tools. An adapted Business Model Canvas (BMC) formed the basic conceptual framework for these tools. Target value = 10 practical exercises; actual value = 11 practical exercises (110%).
Immediately after each training-workshop, participants individually evaluated the training on of four sets of criteria: the relevance of concepts and tools discussed; their satisfaction and the perceived level of innovation; the expected use of the knowledge and skills acquired; and the quality of training-facilitation approach. The activity (closing capitalization workshop) replacing the initial final activity (coaching of young entrepreneurs by trained teachers) was not a training activity that required an extensive evaluation by the participants; although the workshop was globally evaluated as ‘good’. Target value = 3 evaluations realized by trainees; actual value = 2 evaluations realized by trainees (66%).
The evaluations revealed that participants (teachers) very much appreciated face-to-face exchanges with enterprises (field visits, interviews and joint exercises). For many of them, it was a first opportunity to discuss with entrepreneurs on the difficulties they face and explore together options for improving the situation.
More field visits (agri-enterprises) were initially planned for the 2nd training-workshop but the number had to be limited because of COVID-19 measures still inforce; i.e. enterprises were only allowed a small number of visiting teachers which required organizing logistics allowing for all teachers to participate in the visits. Target value = 6 agrifood enterprises visited; actual value = 4 agrifood enterprises visited (66%).

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 19-03-2021: The results of the participants’ evaluation of the 1st training-workshop revealed that 9 out of the 16 concepts and approaches discussed were cited as ‘highly likely’ being used in training and education programs. The other topics achieved scores between 75 and 80% (‘quite likely’). The topics with the highest score (>90%) were ‘assessment of required competencies for entrepreneurs’ and the concept of ‘Base of the Pyramid’. As for the individual score on the intended use of the concepts and approaches discussed, 9% of the participants stated its intended use as ‘likely’, 25% as ‘quite likely’, and 56% of the participants stated its future use as ‘highly likely’. The results of the participants’ evaluation of the 2nd training-workshop indicated that 1 out of the 10 methods and tools discussed was mentioned as ‘highly likely’ being used in training and education programs. The other topics achieved scores between 71 and 80% (quite likely). The tools with the highest score (>75%) were ‘SWOT analysis of enterprises’ and ‘business idea’. As for the individual score on the intended use of methods and tools, 15% of the participants stated its use is ‘likely’, 60% as ‘quite likely’, and 25% of the participants stated its use as ‘highly likely’. On average, 83% of the participants stated that they intend to use the knowledge (concepts and approaches) and skills (use of methods and tools) acquired.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 19-03-2021: The training-workshop participants were teachers from the most relevant departments of the University of Parakou (agronomy, economy and business management, and rural sociology). Four entrepreneurs fully participated in the 2nd training-workshop (Aug 2020) and received advice on how to address certain challenges. The companies are “Takatou” (processing of shea butter; Tchaorou), “Waru” (processing of fruit drinks, Bemberèkè), “Les Meilleurs Prix” (processing of fruit drinks, Parakou), and “Le Moment” (processing and catering of local dishes).

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 19-03-2021: Through the evaluation of the 1st training-workshop, all participants mentioned at least one concept, approach or method/tool that was new to them. The most cited new topics were the business incubation experience of the Start-Up Valley Foundation of the University of Abomey-Calavi (mentioned by 38% of the participants); the concept of Base of the Pyramid (market segment of consumers with low purchasing capacity; also mentioned by 38%); and the concept of agri-food value chains (mentioned by 19% of the participants). At the end of the 2nd training-workshop, 65% of participants mentioned at least one tool that was new for them. This lower percentage as compared to the 100% of the 1st training-workshop might be explained by the fact that the majority of the trainees (13 out of 20) also participated in the 1st training-workshop. The topics that were mainly identified as new were the Business Canvas Model (BMC; mentioned by 25% of the participants); territorial marketing (8%); and coaching-advice of entrepreneurs (also mentioned by 8% of the participants). On average, 82.5% of the participants stated that they have acquired new knowledge (concepts and approaches) and skills (use of methods and tools).

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 19-03-2021: When issuing the call for participation, the appointed UP TMT coordinator particularly targeted female staff in order to raise their interest. However, the relatively low number of female staff in the relevant UP departments – an estimated 15% of total staff - remains a structural constraint for equal participation of female teachers in training-workshops. During the two training-workshops, the participants were equipped with tools allowing for taking in account gender (e.g. framework for assessing women’s economic empowerment, inclusive agribusiness and agrifood enterprise development). Finally yet importantly, women-led enterprises were visited during the 1st training-workshop and female business owners participated in 2nd training-workshop and the closing workshop. The participants of the 2nd training-workshop used their business cases for testing the tools. Through these exercises, female business owners benefitted from advice given by teachers-in-training.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 25-03-2021: A total of 22 teachers of the University of Parakou (UP) participated in the two training workshops; the 1st training-workshop in November 2019 (focus on theory and concepts) and the 2nd in August 2020 (focus on practice and tools). Furthermore, 4 business owners participated in the 2nd training-workshop. These 26 participants included 16 male and 6 female teachers and 2 male and 2 female business owners. 10 teachers (6 men and 4 women) and 3 business owners (2 men and 1 woman) participated in the 3rd closing workshop. These participants were carefully selected in line with the aim of this last workshop, i.e. finalizing the tools used during the 2nd training-workshop and formulating recommendations for institutionalizing the results of the two training-workshops. On average 35% female teachers participated in both training-workshops, but only 3 female teachers (19%) were present in both training-workshops. This is 31% below the target. In fact, female professors are still a minority of UP staff; an estimated 15%.

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 30-03-2021: On average, 17% of the participants evaluated the first (Nov 2019) and second (Aug 2020) training workshop as "very good", and 69% as "good".

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: It is still too early evaluate this indicator. However, the results of the participants’ evaluation of the training-workshops provide some insight into how perceptions changed of agri-food enterprises and entrepreneurs. An ‘unexpected’ outcome was the much-appreciated interaction with agri-entrepreneurs; i.e. field visits and interviews of entrepreneurs (1st and 2nd training-workshop) and presentations by and exercises with entrepreneurs (2nd training-workshop). In fact, 41% of the participants in the 2nd training-workshop cited the sessions during which they interacted with entrepreneurs as the most interesting sessions.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value:
Since the initially final activity of the project – coaching of young and female entrepreneurs – could be organized because of restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic, there is no reliable information available on this indicator.
In terms of enhanced inclusion of socially marginalized groups, the training activities particularly focused on ‘gender’, the position of women in the agrifood sector in Northern Benin, which is traditionally ‘strong’, tools for assessing and improving inclusiveness of business, and the barriers encountered by youth when starting or expanding their business.
